title: Rubio promises more strikes on Venezuelan cartels: ‘We’re not going to sit back anymore’
summary: Secretary of State Marco Rubio says the U.S. will no longer "sit back" on narco-terrorism after President Donald Trump ordered a strike on a Venezuelan cartel boat carrying drugs.
story: Rubio vows more strikes on cartels smuggling arms and drugs from South America.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Wednesday defended President Donald Trump’s strike on a drug cartel-operated vessel off of Venezuela and vowed the U.S. will no longer "sit back" when it comes to "narco-terrorism."

In response to questions about the Marine strike Tuesday that hit a vessel in the southern Caribbean Sea while allegedly carrying members of Tren de Aragua smuggling narcotics headed for the U.S., Rubio said, "We're not going to sit back anymore and watch these people sail up and down the Caribbean like a cruise."

The strike apparently killed 11 members of the group, which was designated a terrorist organization in February, and marked a significant shift from the U.S.’s previous seize-and-apprehend policy when countering international gang networks.
U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio speaks during a press conference at the Secretaria Of Foreign Affairs Building in Mexico City Sept. 3, 2025. (Hector Vivas/Getty Images)
MADURO CLAIMS US SEEKS 'REGIME CHANGE THROUGH MILITARY THREAT' AMID CARIBBEAN BUILDUP

"The president of the United States has determined that narco-terrorist organizations pose a threat to the national security of the United States. I don't need to explain to you why," Rubio said, noting that the group is known to traffic not only drugs, but arms and people.

"These are not stockbrokers. These are not real estate agents who, on the side, deal a few drugs. These are organized, corporate, structured organizations who specialize in the trafficking of deadly drugs into the United States of America," Rubio said. "They pose an immediate threat to the United States. Period."
In speaking to reporters from Mexico, where he was also hashing out counter arms and narcotics agreements, Rubio argued the previous policy of seize and apprehend was ineffective.

"Because these drug cartels, what they do is they know they're going to lose 2% of their cargo — they bake it into their economics," he said. "What will stop them is when you blow them up, when you get rid of them."
Venezuelan vessel destroyed during U.S. military strike. (@realDonaldTrump via Truth Social)
U.S. WARSHIPS TO PATROL INTERNATIONAL WATERS AROUND VENEZUELA AS TRUMP VOWS TO STOP CARTELS

The secretary further pointed out that the arms groups like Tren de Aragua are apparently getting a hold of unconventional weaponry, including drones, and continue to pose an increasingly serious threat to international security.

"We are increasingly concerned that these cartels are now in possession, not just of landmines and grenades. We're now seeing the deployment of drone technology by narco-terrorist groups operating out of Venezuelan territory," he added, noting that they are being used to threaten security forces in neighboring states like Colombia.

The video also showed the suspects getting their hair shaven and walking with their hands behind their necks as they are being transported from the U.S. to El Salvador in March 2025. (@nayibbukele via X)
CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP
Rubio confirmed the strategy employed on Tuesday is how the U.S. will continue to counter international narcotics and arms smuggling.
"It'll happen again. Maybe it's happening right now, I don't know. But the point is the president of the United States is going to wage war on narco-terrorist organizations," Rubio said.
Caitlin McFall is a Reporter at Fox News Digital covering Politics, U.S. and World news.

title: Putin invites Zelenskyy to a meeting in Moscow for security talks as he bombs Ukraine
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin suggests meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Moscow while attending military parade with leaders from China and North Korea.
story: Former national security advisor Robert O’Brien assesses the meeting between Russia, China, North Korea and India and what it means for the U.S. on ‘America Reports.’

Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday claimed he "never refused" a meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and invited him to come to Moscow, according to Russian state-owned news outlet Tass.

"If Zelenskyy is ready for a meeting, let him come to Moscow," Putin said, according to a translation of the remarks issued from China, where he met with Chinese President Xi Jinping and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un for a military parade commemorating the 80th anniversary of World War II.

From left, Russian President Vladimir Putin, Chinese President Xi Jinping, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and Pakistani Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif arrive at a military parade to commemorate the 80th anniversary of Japan's World War II surrender held in front of Tiananmen Gate in Beijing, China, Wednesday, Sept. 3, 2025. (Alexander Kazakov, Sputnik, Kremlin Pool Photo via AP)
TRUMP CLAIMS PUTIN, XI, KIM ARE CONSPIRING AGAINST THE US AFTER MILITARY PARADE IN CHINA
Zelenskyy’s office did not immediately respond to Fox News Digital’s questions, nor did the White House.

Though President Donald Trump told reporters from the Oval Office on Wednesday that he would be speaking with Putin "very shortly," as his two-week deadline issued last month for the Kremlin chief to meet with Zelenskyy is now up.
"I'll know pretty much what we're going to be doing," Trump told reporters. "We've taken very strong action. But I'll be speaking to him over the next few days, and we're going to see.
"I'm going to know exactly what's happening," he added.

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Sybiha took to X and accused Putin of issuing "knowingly unacceptable proposals," adding that seven nations have made known their readiness to host peace talks, including Austria, Vatican City, Switzerland, Turkey, and three Gulf states.

"These are serious proposals and President Zelenskyy is ready for such a meeting at any point of time. Yet, Putin continues to mess around," he added.  "Only increased pressure can force Russia to finally get serious about peace process."
Fox News confirmed that Trump will hold a call with Zelenskyy on Thursday.

U.S. President Donald Trump (R) greets Russian President Vladimir Putin as he arrives at Joint Base Elmendorf-Richardson on Aug. 15, 2025 in Anchorage, Alaska. The two leaders are meeting for peace talks aimed at ending the war in Ukraine. (Getty Images/ Andrew Harnik)
IS PUTIN STRINGING TRUMP ALONG TO SIDESTEP US SANCTIONS WHILE BOMBING UKRAINE?

Zelenskyy has proposed face-to-face meetings with Putin on multiple occasions using a third-party neutral nation like Turkey, though the Kremlin chief has thus far never agreed to engage directly with the Ukrainian president.

Putin on Wednesday claimed that if a "meeting is well-prepared and will lead to some positive results," then he would agree to meet. He also claimed Zelenskyy was "afraid" to meet with him, though he did not detail why he believed this.
Any possibility of Zelenskyy traveling to Russia appears highly unlikely given the threats he would face, and the fact that Putin has made clear his chief aim is to oust Zelenskyy from Kyiv.
Former CIA Moscow Station Chief Dan Hoffman echoed these security concerns and told Fox News Digital, "There’s no way that Zelenskyy should be traveling to Moscow."

"Putin invaded Ukraine," Hoffman said. "[Putin] is doing this to make it appear as if he will negotiate in good faith and try and drive a wedge between Zelenskyy and the United States, as well as Zelenskyy and Europe."
Firefighters work on the site of a burning building after a Russian attack in Kyiv, Ukraine, early Thursday, Aug. 28, 2025. (AP Photo/Efrem Lukatsky)
CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP
While European leaders have staunchly backed Zelenskyy in opposition to Putin, Trump’s position has remained more ambiguous since entering office.
In answer questions by reporters on Tuesday over whether there will be "consequences" if a meeting between Putin and Zelenskyy is not announced soon, Trump said, "Yeah, there will be."
It is unclear if Trump will believe Putin is extending a good-faith offer to meet with Zelenskyy or see it as a false attempt at statesmanship as he continues to heavily attack Ukraine.
Fox News' Pat Ward contributed to this report.
Caitlin McFall is a Reporter at Fox News Digital covering Politics, U.S. and World news.

title: House Democrats release lewd birthday note Trump allegedly sent to Epstein
summary: House Democrats on Monday posted on X an image of a birthday message that President Donald Trump allegedly sent to Jeffrey Epstein in 2003
story: House Democrats on Monday posted on X an image of a birthday message that President Donald Trump allegedly sent to Jeffrey Epstein in 2003.
Trump has denied having anything to do with the card, which was included in a leather-bound book of birthday messages for the late convicted sex offender's 50th birthday.
The book was among the documents that the House Oversight Committee had subpoenaed from Epstein's estate last month.

The Wall Street Journal was first to report the existence of the card. Trump sued the Journal, its publisher and two reporters in July. A spokesperson for Dow Jones said the newspaper stood by its reporting and would "vigorously defend against any lawsuit."

NBC News has not independently verified the Journal’s reporting. White House deputy chief of staff Taylor Budowich posted on X that the note should help Trump’s legal case because “it’s not his signature.” He added numerous photos of Trump’s current signature, where he signed his full name.

The post shows a hand-drawn outline of a naked woman with Trump's first name signed in the pubic area, as well as a typewritten note depicting an imaginary conversation between the future president and the multimillionaire who would later be charged with sex trafficking.
“Voice Over: There must be more to life than having everything," the note begins.
"Donald: Yes, there is, but I won’t tell you what it is," it continues.
"Nor will I, since I also know what it is," Jeffrey says.
Donald says, "We have certain things in common Jeffrey," and he responds, "Yes, we do, come to think of it."
Donald then says, "Enigmas never age, have you noticed that?" Jeffrey responds, "As a matter of fact, it was clear to me the last time I saw you."

It concludes with Donald telling Jeffrey that "A pal is a wonderful thing. Happy Birthday — and may every day be another wonderful secret.” Trump's full name is typed out above the "Donald" signature.
Trump said on his social media platform in July, "These are not my words, not the way I talk. Also, I don’t draw pictures."
Shortly after that post, the Washington Post ran a story noting that he'd done four sketches of buildings and a bridge that had been auctioned off during his first term as president.

Days later, he amended his earlier statement while talking to reporters. "Sometimes people say, 'Would you draw a building?' And I’ll draw four lines and a little roof, you know, for a charity. So, but, but I’m not a drawing person. I don’t do drawings of women, that I can tell you," he said on July 28.
In his defamation suit, Trump's attorneys alleged the note was "nonexistent" and that "no authentic letter or drawing exists."
His attorneys did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

The version of the book that the Oversight Committee received was redacted to not show the names and faces of women and minors, according to the production cover letter sent from the Epstein estate attorneys to the committee.
The subpoena from the committee said the book had been put together by Epstein's accomplice, Ghislaine Maxwell, who is serving a 20-year sentence for sex trafficking.

Maxwell was questioned about the existence of the book when she met with Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche in July. She acknowledged she coordinated the project and had asked some of Epstein's friends to contribute birthday wishes, but said she did not recall if she'd spoken to Trump about the project or whether he'd submitted anything.
Trump and Epstein were friends at one point, though the president has said they had a falling out years before Epstein’s arrest for sex trafficking.
Maxwell is appealing her conviction to the Supreme Court and her attorney has said he hopes Trump will give her a pardon.

An Oversight Committee aide said that, in addition to the birthday book, the estate also turned over Epstein's will, the Sept. 24, 2007, nonprosecution agreement between the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of Florida and Epstein; entries from Epstein’s address/contact books from Jan. 1, 1990, through Aug. 10, 2019; and information about his bank accounts.
"Committee staff will review these documents and make them public in the near future,” the aide said.
Epstein died by suicide in his jail cell while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges in New York in 2019. His death sparked years of conspiracy theories, some pushed by allies of Trump.

The case exploded back into the headlines this summer after the Justice Department and the FBI announced in an unsigned joint memo that they agreed Epstein’s death was the result of a suicide, that no other people were expected to be charged and that no further information about the case would be released.

The unexpected move sparked a furious backlash from many Trump supporters, since he and his allies had stoked conspiracy theories about the politically connected Epstein’s death and had vowed to be transparent and bring others to justice in the case.

The House Oversight Committee also subpoenaed the Justice Department for its investigative files. The DOJ has turned over about a third of the files so far, and Democrats have said that the vast majority of that material was already public.

title: Supreme Court allows Trump to fire FTC commissioner
summary: The Supreme Court on Monday allowed President Donald Trump to fire a member of the Federal Trade Commission despite a federal law that is intended to restrict the White House’s power to control the agency.
story: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday allowed President Donald Trump to fire a member of the Federal Trade Commission despite a federal law that is intended to restrict the White House’s power to control the agency.
The court, via an order issued by Chief Justice John Roberts, temporarily blocked a judge's ruling that reinstated Rebecca Kelly Slaughter while the case continues.

The order did not definitively signal how the court would address an emergency request made by the Trump administration to give the president broader authority to fire independent agency members without cause, but signals that it would likely grant it.

Slaughter, who briefly returned to the agency as a result of the lower court rulings, said in a statement she would "see this case through to the end" regardless of the court's decision to let Trump remove her while the litigation continues.

"In the week I was back at the FTC it became even more clear to me that we desperately need the transparency and accountability Congress intended to have at bipartisan independent agencies," she added.

Trump fired both Democratic commissioners on the five-person FTC in March, Slaughter and Alvaro Bedoya. Both challenged the move, although Bedoya later dropped out of the case. Slaughter is currently listed as a serving commissioner on the agency’s website, as the case has made its way through the courts.

The firings are a direct challenge to a 1935 Supreme Court precedent called Humphrey's Executor v. United States that upheld limits on the president’s ability to fire FTC commissioners without cause, a restriction Congress imposed to protect the agency from political pressure.
Under the 1914 law that set up the agency, members can only be removed for “inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office.”
A federal judge in July ruled in favor of Slaughter, citing the 1935 ruling. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit reached a similar conclusion.

But the Supreme Court, whose majority has been skeptical of the concept of independent federal agencies that are not subject to presidential control, has undermined such protections in recent years in a series of cases involving other agencies.
Lawyers for the Trump administration argue that the removal restrictions unlawfully impose limits on the president's power to control the executive branch as defined by Article 2 of the Constitution.
This year, Trump has also sought to remove members of other independent federal agencies, which the Supreme Court has allowed.

The FTC has five commissioners who serve seven-year terms —with no more than three from one political party. Slaughter and Bedoya both served as Democratic members, although Trump originally appointed Bedoya in 2018. President Joe Biden reappointed her in 2024.

title: Trump asks Supreme Court to allow $4 billion in foreign aid cuts
summary: The Trump administration asked the Supreme Court to allow the government to withhold $4 billion of spending on foreign aid that was approved by Congress.
story: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Monday asked the Supreme Court to allow the government to withhold $4 billion of spending on foreign aid that was approved by Congress.
The move came in response to a federal judge's ruling last week that requires the administration to spend the funds despite President Donald Trump notifying Congress that he intends not to.

The case marks a showdown over to what extent the president can refuse to spend money that Congress has appropriated, a brewing issue as Trump has embraced a sweeping view of presidential power since taking office again in January.
In the new filing, Solicitor General D. John Sauer described the case as raising “a grave and urgent threat” to the power of the presidency.
Under the Constitution, it is the job of Congress to allocate funds that the president can spend.
Current federal funding expires on Sept. 30. The Trump administration has said it wants to withhold $4 billion in foreign aid, but will spend another $6.5 billion that Congress appropriated.

The dispute involves a law called the Impoundment Control Act, which was passed in 1974 to regulate the president’s control over the budget. That followed efforts by then-President Richard Nixon to withhold spending on programs he did not support.

Washington-based U.S. District Judge Amir Ali has been at the center of the complicated litigation, which has raged for months as the Trump administration has dismantled the U.S. Agency for International Development.
The underlying lawsuit was brought by various groups that receive foreign-aid funding, led by the Global Health Council.
Prior to the current administration, USAID spent billions every year on programs in developing countries addressing such issues as malaria and AIDs prevention and improving access to water.
In his ruling last week, Ali said the government must spend the money unless Congress votes to approve Trump's request.
But in Monday's filing, Sauer said that Ali's order imposes impossible burdens on the administration.

"To have any hope of complying in time, the executive branch would have to immediately commence diplomatic discussions with foreign nations about the use of those funds — discussions the President considers counterproductive to foreign policy — and notify Congress about planned obligations that the President is strongly opposing," he added.

In a filing in response, the plaintiffs urged the court not to immediately block Ali's ruling, saying it merely requires the government to make plans to spend the money by the end of the month. If Congress approves Trump's request, the money would not have to be spent, they added.
On Friday, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit declined to block Ali's decision, prompting the Trump administration to turn to the Supreme Court.

The Trump administration filing is the 25th emergency request from the government since January, as courts have pushed back against broad assertions of presidential authority. The Supreme Court, which has a 6-3 conservative majority, has granted 17 of the requests.

title: New tariff rules bring 'maximum chaos' as surprise charges hit consumers
summary: The bills are sudden and jarring: $1,400 for a computer part from Germany, $620 for an aluminum case from Sweden and $1,041 for handbags from Spain
story: The bills are sudden and jarring: $1,400 for a computer part from Germany, $620 for an aluminum case from Sweden and $1,041 for handbags from Spain.

Some U.S. shoppers say they are being hit with surprise charges from international shipping carriers as the exemption on import duties for items under $800 expires as a part of President Donald Trump’s tariff push.
That’s leading to some frustration and confusion as shoppers and shippers both try to navigate a new reality for anybody ordering goods from abroad.
“It’s maximum chaos,” said Nick Baker, co-lead of the trade and customs practice at Kroll, a firm that advises freight carriers.

Thomas Andrews, who runs a business in upstate New York restoring vintage computers from the 1980s and 1990s, said he was shocked to receive a tariff bill from DHL for approximately $1,400 on a part worth $750. He said he assumed there must have been a mistake.
“That’s extortion,” Andrews said.

Late Friday, a representative for DHL told Andrews that the initial charge was indeed incorrect: The tariff bill should have only been for about $110. But it was too late: Andrews had already refused shipment to avoid paying the charge. Soon after learning about the corrected charge, he realized DHL had already begun sending the item back to Germany.
The final annoyance, Andrews said: He’s being charged for the return shipping — about $50.

On Aug. 29, for the first time in nearly a century, small-dollar items coming into the U.S. — also called de minimis goods — began facing import duties. That means even small, personal orders now face the sizable tariffs placed on U.S. trading partners. While a recent ruling by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit found many of Trump’s duties unconstitutional, they remain in effect while Trump appeals the case to the Supreme Court.
To comply with the new de minimis rules, a wave of countries have halted shipments to the U.S. That’s caused postal traffic into the U.S. to decline by some 80%, according to a United Nations agency.

But many orders are still flowing. And since the new de minimis rule began taking effect, social media platforms have been filled with accounts of U.S. customers receiving shock bills from major shippers like DHL, FedEx and UPS, having received no notice about the charges from the foreign merchant they’d ordered from.
The shippers, in turn, are being inundated with messages from customers disputing the charges, along with return-to-sender requests as the customers refuse shipments to avoid having to pay the bills.
A representative for DHL said the firm “is committed to supporting customers through the recent tariff changes and ensuring their shipments are managed efficiently.”
“We encourage customers to take note of the shipping policies of the brands they shop with and to also remember that tariffs are payable to the U.S. government,” it said.

The Trump administration has heralded the billions in revenues the tariffs are bringing in — and in the case of the new de minimis rule, argued the change is essential to halting the flow of small-sized illicit drug packages and drug ingredients. In a statement posted the day the new de minimis rules took effect, U.S. Customs and Border Protection said the logistics industry “has already adapted to the changes with minimal interruption.”

“This change has been months in the making, and we are fully prepared to implement it,” said Susan S. Thomas, acting executive assistant commissioner for CBP’s Office of Trade. “Foreign carriers and postal operators were given clear timelines, detailed guidance, and multiple options to comply. The only thing ending on August 29 is the pathway that has been used by criminals to exploit America’s borders.”

Baker said foreign merchants are obligated to provide information to the shipper about the classification of the item, which is key to the tariff calculation — but from a regulatory perspective, the customer, as the importer of record, is ultimately responsible for the accuracy of that information.
But many people are still getting caught off guard.
After receiving a tariff bill for $620 on a $300 aluminum computer case from Sweden, Robert Wang decided to turn the shipment away.
A software engineer in the San Francisco Bay Area, Wang said he placed his order Aug. 22 with Louqe, a high-end Swedish merchant. More than a week later, he received notice from UPS about the bill.

“Confusion transitioned into a late-night panic,” Wang said, as he frantically researched the situation. Eventually UPS confirmed he’d been charged the 200% tariff Trump has slapped on certain aluminum goods.
Wang said he tried to reach out to Louqe about the charge, but did not hear back. The company did not respond to a request for comment from NBC News.
In a statement, UPS said it has solutions available to merchants designed to navigate the new environment, but did not address the customer-billing situation.

Baker said many foreign businesses that rely on U.S. customers now face the dilemma of eating the tariff cost — assuming they are properly accounting for it in the first place — or passing it on to their customers, which could scare off business. Many merchants abroad have posted to social media to alert U.S. customers that they are suspending shipments there.

Some U.S. small businesses are also paying a price. A day after receiving a shipment from Spain for handbags he said were worth about $600, Herm Narciso said he and his wife, who run a brick-and-mortar shop in Dunedin, Florida, that resells goods from Europe, got a tariff invoice for $1,041.44 from DHL.
“We can’t understand how it’s possible to assess us with that level of tariffs,” Narciso said.

They said that they plan to file a dispute, but that the response could take two to four weeks. Narciso is worried their shop won’t survive the recent changes if they start getting similar bills going forward.
“This last quarter is probably going to tank us,” Narciso said. “The margins on this type of business are slim to begin with.”
He added: “It just doesn’t feel like the American way to me.”

title: French Parliament ousts second PM in less than a year, fueling instability
summary: France's National Assembly is set to vote for a motion of no confidence in François Bayrou, less than a year after they did the same for Michel Barnier.
story: The French government was thrown into fresh turmoil Monday as lawmakers fired the prime minister, the latest leader tossed out by a deeply divided legislature.

Parliamentarians on the left and right voted against François Bayrou in a motion of no confidence. They are unhappy about his proposal to make drastic cuts of around 44 billion euros ($51 billion) to next year’s budget, an unpopular attempt to resolve France’s economic woes.

This was the second time in nine months that lawmakers in France’s National Assembly ousted a prime minister; Michel Barnier was deposed in a vote of no confidence in December. Before that, the last successful vote of no confidence was in 1962. It means French President Emmanuel Macron will be looking for his fifth prime minister in just 20 months.

Though Macron remains a big presence internationally — leading European efforts to support Ukraine and provide a counterweight to President Donald Trump — at home he is dogged by a divided electorate and long-term uncertainty.

Macron, in his second term, is barred by term limits from running  in the next presidential election in 2027. The far-right National Rally is currently leading the polls, even though its leader, Marine le Pen, is  barred from office because of an embezzlement conviction, which she is appealing.

As in the rest of Europe, the far right is surging in France, capitalizing on widespread discontent over a cost-of-living crisis that has fueled a rise in anti-immigrant sentiment. And on Wednesday, large anti-government protests are expected throughout France.

France’s troubles took root last year when Le Pen’s National Rally performed well in Europe-wide elections and Macron stunned the Continent by calling snap parliamentary elections. Parties on the left and right were able to work together to block a victory for Le Pen, but the resulting Parliament was divided, with no group holding enough power to govern with stability.

Macron cobbled together a minority government, but as Bayrou and Barnier have found, it is extremely vulnerable to attack by its leftist and hard-right opponents. Many French political experts  say the current crisis will persist until 2027 when the country elects a new leader, who will inevitably seek to cement their mandate by calling fresh parliamentary elections.
This will do little to resolve France’s short-term economic woes. Both Bayrou and Barnier were ousted while trying to resolve what they and many others see as a national debt crisis.

France’s budget deficit — how much more it spends than it earns — last year reached 5.8% of its gross domestic product. That’s far higher than the European Union average of 3.1% and the E.U.’s target of 3%, worrying investors about rising interest rates, lower credit ratings and less money for public services in the future.

title: Howard Stern is not leaving his SiriusXM radio show, pulling a prank with Andy Cohen
summary: Howard Stern trolled listeners on Monday with a joke that he was leaving his longtime SiriusXM radio show and would be replaced by Andy Cohen.
story: Howard Stern trolled listeners on Monday with a joke that he was leaving his longtime SiriusXM radio show and would be replaced by Andy Cohen.
"The point is, none of this was real," Stern said, who later confirmed he is staying on the show.
SiriusXM declined to comment.
The prank began at the top of the 7 a.m. time slot when Cohen told listeners that he was rebranding Stern's channel as "Andy 100."

"This is not the voice you probably wanted to hear, but it is I, Andy Cohen, and this is our first day broadcasting on Channel 100. Andy 100 is what it’s being referred to around Sirius for the last few days. I know that you’re expecting a big announcement from Howard, and this is not how things were meant to go,” he said.
Cohen continued: "There’s been a lot of talk about what’s going to happen with Howard’s deal. Is he fired? I don’t know how much I’m allowed to say, except that he’s not here and I am."
The Bravo host went on to say that it was supposed to be "a cleaner handoff," but "there’s nothing clean about it."
“I’m kind of winging it,” Cohen said.
Multiple news outlets, including Variety and the Associated Press, reported that Stern was leaving the network.

But after a break, Stern came on air and revealed the elaborate prank. He thanked Cohen "for that little bit," telling listeners that the news of his departure was a gag he set up with the Bravo host.

"That was all masterminded by me," Stern said. "I said to Andy, would you cut a bit for us? And he immediately said yes. I said go as long as you want because the longer it goes on, the more people think it’s real. And Andy had no problem with that. He’s the best. … Love him for doing that. Thank you, Andy Cohen, and Andy 100."
The longtime radio personality expressed frustrations over rumors in recent weeks that he had been fired from SiriusXM.
"I don’t even know what woke means, but we’ll get to that, because that’s the reason I was fired from Sirius," he said, sarcastically.
Stern continued: "Everything you’ve been reading in the paper about me, about [co-host] Robin [Quivers], are completely false."
Stern said last week he wasn’t on air because of a cold he’s been battling.

title: 23-year-old Ukrainian refugee killed on North Carolina transit system
summary: North Carolina police are investigating the slaying of a 23-year-old Ukrainian woman on board a Charlotte Area Transit System train last month.
story: North Carolina police are investigating the slaying of a 23-year-old Ukrainian woman on board a Charlotte Area Transit System train last month.

The victim, who was identified by police as Iryna Zarutska, had recently come to the U.S. from Ukraine to escape the war with Russia, according to a GoFundMe started by her family. Her death has generated national attention and outrage from President Donald Trump.

Officers from the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department responded to the 1800 block of Camden Road following a call reporting an assault with a deadly weapon on Aug. 22, according to a police news release. Zarutska had been stabbed on the LYNX Blue Line train near the light rail station, WCNC reported.
Officers found the 23-year-old had sustained knife wounds, and she was pronounced dead on the scene, police said.

Decarlos Brown Jr., 34, was identified as a suspect in the stabbing, police said. He was taken to a local hospital "with non-life-threatening injuries sustained at the time of the incident" and will be arrested and charged with first-degree murder upon his release.

Surveillance video obtained by WBTV shows someone who appears to be Zarutska getting on a full train and sitting in front of a person who appears to be Brown. After a few minutes, the person reported to be Brown seemingly takes out a pocket knife, stands up, and allegedly stabs the individual sitting in front of him. There did not appear to be any interaction between the two people before the alleged stabbing.
In a statement, Charlotte Mayor Vi Lyles called the incident "a senseless and tragic loss."

"My prayers remain with her loved ones as they continue to grieve through an unimaginable time. Like so many of you, I’m heartbroken — and I’ve been thinking hard about what safety really looks like in our city," Lyles said. "I remain committed to doing all we can to protect our residents and ensure Charlotte is a place where everyone feels safe."
Zarutska had recently left Ukraine "seeking safety from the war and hoping for a new beginning," according to GoFundMe, seeking support for her aunt and uncle with funeral expenses.

Trump mentioned the stabbing Monday while delivering remarks during the second hearing of the Religious Liberty Commission in Washington, D.C., saying, "there are evil people, and we have to confront that."

"A lunatic just got up and started — it’s right on the tape, not, not really watchable, because it’s so horrible," he said. "But just viciously stabbed. She’s just sitting there. So, there are evil people. We have to be able to handle that. If we don’t handle that, we don’t have a country."
Her death has also spurred rebukes from others on the right, who have accused the media of purposely not covering the incident.
White House Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller blamed the Democratic Party for the incident.

"The Democrat Party at every level — judges, politicians, academics, nonprofits — is organized around the defense and protection of the criminal, the monstrous and the depraved," he wrote in a post on X. "The more vile the threat, the more vociferously the Democrat Party works to protect and enable it."
Elon Musk, who formerly held an unofficial advisory role in the Trump administration, commented on the incident in several posts on X.

“Let’s change the law,” Musk wrote in one X post. "Between now and then, name and shame the DAs and judges who enable murder, rape and robbery. But especially shame those who funded the campaigns of the DAs and judges. That will make the biggest difference."
The investigation into the attack is ongoing.

title: Debby Ryan and Husband Josh Dun of Twenty One Pilots Expecting Their 1st Child — See Pics
summary: Former Disney star Debby Ryan and her husband, Josh Dun of Twenty One Pilots. have announced she is pregnant with their first child.
story: Debby Ryan and Josh Dun's lives are about to get a bit sweeter.
In a joint Instagram post on Sept. 7, the couple announced they're expecting their first child together and shared several photos of Ryan's baby bump.
In the first photo, the former Disney actor sports a lacy white top that shows off her bump while her husband holds a pair of mini-shoes and kisses his wife.
They captioned the post, “dun&dun +one.”

The expectant mother, 32, first rose to fame as a young TV star, appearing in several series, including “Jessie” and “The Suite Life on Deck.” Meanwhile, her musician husband is a drummer and a member of the band Twenty One Pilots.
Elsewhere in the photo carousel, the couple shared a sweet image of Dun touching hands with his wife as he places a hand on her stomach.
The couple also posted a photo of their baby's sonogram.
In the last photo, Ryan holds on to her stomach as she poses in the bathroom.
Other celebrities were quick to offer their messages of support in the comments section.
Pierson Fodé, who starred alongside Ryan in "Jessie," kept his message simple, writing, "Congrats!!!!" with raised hands emoji.
Karan Brar, who also appeared in the show, could barely hide his excitement with his comment, which read "IM LOSING IT" with crying emoji.
"So thrilled for you and Josh! Sending you lots of love and good vibes!" Kevin Chamberlin, who played Bertram in the series, commented.
Former Disney star Hayley Kiyoko also weighed in, writing, "So happy for you guys!!!"
"Emily in Paris" star Lily Collins, who announced that she had welcomed her first child in January, was thrilled to hear the news and commented, "Eeeeeeee yayyyyyyyyy congratulations!!!"
"Modern Family" star Sarah Hyland also shared her well wishes, writing, "AHHHH IS IT MINE???? ( just joshin ya @joshuadun 😜)."
The couple's fans also weighed in, with one writing, "Finally, the 22nd pilot."
Some fans even suggested possible names for baby Dun.
"Name the baby Jessie," one wrote.
"If it's a girl: Radio," one wrote, referring to Ryan's TV movie "Radio Rebel." "If it's a boy: Rebel."

Ryan and Dun married on New Year's Eve in 2019. In December 2023, Ryan paid tribute to her husband on their anniversary on Instagram, writing, "Four years wed - thanks for running lines with me and all the great meals we ate and troubleshooting my technology and carrying me to bed when I'm drowsy and mostly for your perspective & your character. I fell in love this year more. please never die and never stop kissing me."

title: Malin Åkerman Reacts to Shocking ‘Hunting Wives’ Ending and Her Favorite ’Tender’ Margo-Sophie Moments
summary: Malin Åkerman talks in an interview with TODAY.com about her friendship with "Hunting Wives" co-star Brittany Snow, favorite scenes, Margo and the show's ending.
story: Warning: This story contains spoilers from “The Hunting Wives” book and television series.
Just like Margo and Sophie’s unforgettable time in the truck, Malin Åkerman and Brittany Snow have been on the ride of a lifetime after the wild success of “The Hunting Wives.”
“I love Brittany so much,” Åkerman tells TODAY.com. “She’s just a gem.”

The actors from the hit series, which is streaming on Netflix and is an adaptation of author May Cobb’s book of the same name, have been everywhere lately after the audience became captivated by their characters — and their relationship — in the show.

Åkerman portrays the mesmerizing and complicated Margo Banks, who’s married to the town’s aspiring politician, Jed Banks (Dermot Mulroney), and is the center of a good-time girlfriend group in east Texas. Snow’s Sophie O’Neil and her husband, Graham O’Neil (Evan Jonigkeit), are new to town, and Sophie quickly falls in with the group, especially Margo, whom she also starts to see on the side romantically.
Malin Åkerman on Her Friendship and Chemistry With Brittany Snow

The two are coming off a weekend of presenting at both the Creative Arts Emmys in LA and the 2025 MTV VMAs in New York. Both posted about the events on social media, gushing about being each other’s “perfect date.”

“To get to spend two nights, like, run off to the airport and fly together … has been incredible,” Åkerman says, adding they hadn't seen each other since their show dropped in July and subsequently took off.
“It was a really special weekend to celebrate,” she says. “We had a few glasses of Champagne.”
Åkerman says before the show, she and Snow had previously run into each other but “never really got to chatting.”

“We just became fast friends,” she says. “We went out for dinner to try to start to get to know each other, and after that dinner, it was just like, ‘Oh my God. We are cut from the same cloth, a lot of similar backgrounds.’ And so, we just connected immediately.”
“The Hunting Wives” showrunner Rebecca Cutter previously said there were not chemistry reads with Åkerman and Snow before filming.

“We got really lucky that we truly loved each other,” Åkerman says. “We are now really great friends. The energy was just right. The casting director was incredible. Somehow she knew the magic that was going to happen, and it really did.”
Malin Åkerman Talks Margo-Sophie Scenes in 'The Hunting Wives'
Their connection came across on screen in Margo and Sophie’s many scenes, including the more intimate ones.
“There’s some beautiful ones — in bed, post-everything, where I just think there are some tender moments between the two of them that I love,” Åkerman says.
One of her favorites is from Episode 1, when Margo makes a pit stop in a parking lot while driving Sophie home.

“I think the super fun one is us in the truck and doing doughnuts, that whole scene outside,” Åkerman says. “Even though it was freezing that night, we were both just shivering hoping that nobody could tell, but we had a lot of fun shooting that scene. That was great.”
Cutter previously told TODAY.com her favorite scene between the two characters is from the same night, before Margo and Sophie go their separate ways.

“I love the moment when Margo’s dropping her off in that first episode, and she’s like, ‘Oh, we’re going to have so much fun together. I love you.’ And Sophie goes, ‘I love you, too.’ It was exactly how I pictured it when I wrote it,” she said.

“Brittany is putting all those levels into it where you’re like, ‘Wait, does she love her love her?’ She’s not just saying it back in the same tone that Margo was saying it. That’s for sure,” she added.
Åkerman says that scene is “amazing.”
“I love Brittany’s performance in that. It’s just — she’s so cute.”
Did Malin Åkerman Play Margo Like She Was in Love With Sophie?
Snow said in an interview that she played the character of Sophie like she was in love with Margo, but did Åkerman portray Margo like she was in love with Sophie?

“Margo is complicated,” Åkerman explains. “She has many, many nuances, and I think sometimes she is truly in love with Sophie, but I think it’s hard for someone like Margo to really come out of her narcissism because she is her No. 1. And she takes care of No. 1. So she will easily throw anyone under the bus if that means that she will survive.
“There’s a love story there for sure, but again, you be careful with Margo.”

Margo’s complicated background and tendencies stem from her rough upbringing, which is shown in flashbacks and through her relationship with her brother, Kyle. In the show's final moments, Sophie kills Kyle, unbeknownst to Margo, who was previously revealed as the killer at the center of the show’s murder of a local teenager named Abby.
Malin Åkerman Reacts to 'The Hunting Wives' Ending and Margo as the Killer
“We are so worried for them,” Åkerman says of Margo and Sophie.
“Now you have two murderers together. So they can continue their love story,” she adds with a laugh.

Margo being the killer in the TV adaptation differs from the book, where Jill, portrayed by Katie Lowes in the show, is the murderer. Margo also dies at the end of the novel but is still alive in the series.
Cutter told TODAY.com she knew after reading the book, and “well before” Åkerman was cast, that she wanted to change who the killer was.
“I knew I wanted her to do it, and I knew I wanted her to stay alive,” she said.
Åkerman explains that despite knowing the ending of the show, she was “equally as shocked” as everyone else after watching it “because it was so well filmed and done.”
“I loved that Rebecca changed who the killer was, and I know that May Cobb was on board, too, and she loved it,” Åkerman says.
Cobb previously told TODAY.com that Cutter made the show “even more unapologetic and juicy and bonkers than the book.”
Åkerman is grateful for fans who read the book and also enjoyed the series.

“You never know when you change, and especially an ending and a big plot point like that, some fans can get angry,” she says. “But I think everyone enjoyed this, and we have to have Margo Banks back. She can’t die.”
Without Margo Banks, fans wouldn’t have their beloved Margo-Sophie ship, which has fueled multiple fan edits on social media, compiling some of their sweetest moments together set to love songs.

“It’s so cool — there’s some brilliant edits out there,” Åkerman says. “I’ve reposted some of them. There’s too many to repost, really, but it’s so fun to see people enjoy it so much. And see people enjoy that relationship and create that love story, their own love story, from these characters. It’s wonderful.”

While there are many beautiful scenes between Margo and Sophie, there are also some dark ones. One that Åkerman didn’t particularly enjoy is in the back half of the series, when Margo shows up at Sophie’s motel room, where Sophie stays after Graham kicks her out of the house while the police suspect her of Abby’s murder.

“What wasn’t my favorite is the one in the motel where Brittany chokes me, and I smack her, and we hated that,” Åkerman says. “We hated hating each other, but it turned out beautiful. But there was a lot of, ‘I’m so sorry. I don’t want to do this.’”
As for when viewers will see what’s next for Margo and Sophie, that remains to be seen. The show has not yet officially been picked up for a second season.

“I wish I was here with better news, but I feel like we all know there’s going to be a second season, without confirming,” she told Jenna Bush Hager and guest co-host Savannah Guthrie on the fourth hour of TODAY on Sept. 8.

title: Country Singer Drake White and Wife Alex Share Loss of Daughter Born at 29 Weeks
summary: Country singer Drake White and his wife, Alex,  announced the loss of their daughter, Della Elizabeth, who died 20 minutes after she was born at 29 weeks.
story: Country singer Drake White and his wife, Alex, have announced the death of their newborn daughter in a joint post shared Sept. 7 on their respective Instagram pages.
The couple revealed Della Elizabeth White was born at 29 weeks and died 20 minutes after her birth.
“On Sunday, August 31st our precious daughter, Della Elizabeth White, went peacefully to be with Jesus,” the post began.

“We are so thankful for the holy moments God gave us with her. The Lord has been so near and close to us during this difficult time. He has held us up and sustained us through it all. We are heartbroken and soul tired, but we know we will get through this difficult time with the strength, peace, and joy that only our Heavenly Father can provide. May Della be held in the arms of Jesus until we see her again someday.”
The post also featured a pair of Bible verses.
“‘The Lord is close to the brokenhearted and saves those who are crushed in spirit.’ -Psalm 34:18,” the couple wrote.

“‘I am dying from my grief; my years are shortened by sadness,’” the post continued. “‘Misery has drained my strength; I am wasting away from within. But I am trusting you, O Lord, saying, "You are my God!" My future is in your hands.’ - Psalm 31:10, 14-15.”
The post also said Della weighed 3 pounds, 3 1/2 ounces when she was born Aug. 31 at 8:52 a.m. before dying at 9:12 a.m.
The country music community sent condolences.

“I am so sorry. I love you and I’m praying for you all. No one should ever go through this kind of pain. I know your sweet girl will always be in your heart and watching over you,” Jessie James Decker wrote in the comments.
“My hearts aches for you. Sending so much love and prayer your way,” Lauren Alaina wrote.
“Love you buddy,” commented Chase Rice.
“I am so so very incredibly sorry to hear this,” Terri Clark wrote. “Heartbroken for you both. Sending you both love. No one should ever have to go through the loss of a child.”
Drake and Alex White are parents to a son, William, 2. In May, they confirmed they were expecting their second child.
“We were able to conceive through IVF and had our frozen embryo transfer in March,” Alex White told People. “We found out we were pregnant 10 days later and are due in November.”
Prior to William’s birth in 2023, Drake White reflected on the long road he and his wife took to get to that point.

“We’ve been through so much, from my having a stroke on stage to Alex being diagnosed with type 1 diabetes and having an autoimmune disorder,” he told People. “And then this was just something else that tested our faith and tested our strength.”
“For six years, we have prayed for a baby and to know that God has heard our prayers is honestly overwhelming,” Alex White said.

title: Is Howard Stern Leaving SiriusXM?
summary: Howard Stern is setting the record straight about the future of his radio show
story: Howard Stern is setting the record straight about the future of his radio show.
The 71-year-old appeared to get the last laugh on the Sept. 8 episode of "The Howard Stern Show" when he addressed rumors of his departure and executed an elaborate ruse with the help of Andy Cohen.
What prompted the comedic stunt and what's really going on with Stern's radio show? We're breaking down everything you need to know.
Why Do People Think Howard Stern Is Leaving His Radio Show?
Over the summer, several rumors started to spread about Stern's show.
Some surrounded the health of Stern's co-host, Robin Quivers. While appearing on "The Howard Stern Show" on Sept. 8, Quivers put those rumors to rest for good while Stern recounted how they started.
"The long story short is, during the summer, some dude picked up the phone, called TMZ and said, 'Hey, Robin died,'" he said.
Shortly afterwards, Stern explained, rumors emerged that he had been fired.
"So then all of a sudden, I’m sitting home and everybody I know in my world, even peripherally, is writing me, 'Are you OK?'" he recalled on air.
Stern, whose five-year contract with SiriusXM expires later this year, went on to say he "got really upset" over the matter.
"I was like, you know, 'What the f--- do you mean I got fired? How does anybody know I got fired?'" he said.
Howard Stern Promised His Listeners Answers to All Their Questions
Before the Sept. 2 episode of "The Howard Stern Show," the radio show's Instagram page teased Stern's return.
"Fired? Retiring? Canceled? Bye-Bye Booey? Howard Stern will speak. Tuesday, September 2. Only on @siriusxm," the post read.
The episode was later rescheduled to Sept. 8 when Stern fell ill, as he explained on air.
Andy Cohen Appeared on Stern's Show to Announce He Was Replacing Him
The Sept. 8 episode of "The Howard Stern Show" began with Bravo impresario Andy Cohen's voice.

"I know that you’re expecting a big announcement from Howard, and this is not how things were meant to go. There’s been a lot of talk about what’s going to happen with Howard’s deal. Is he fired? I don’t know how much I’m allowed to say, except that he’s not here and I am," Cohen said.
"Howard was supposed to start the show today, and this was supposed to be something of a cleaner handoff. There is nothing clean about it. Here we are. I’m kind of winging it."
Cohen acknowledged that he was "filling in for the biggest shoes" and said he wasn't supposed to take over for Stern until December.

"But so much has happened over the last week, and Howard and the executive team here at serious felt it was best to kind of part ways now. I haven’t spoken to Howard. I have a call into him and a text into him. I know he is someone who feels big. He has a lot of emotions, and I’m sure that he is feeling big right now, and I’m hoping that you will hear from him, and I’m hoping that you’ll hear from him right here at some point," he added.
After a few moments, Stern appeared to announce that Cohen was not taking over for him.

But by then, news had spread — some outlets published the false news that Cohen had replaced Stern. When Stern did appear on air, he addressed the speedy reporting, saying, "Already, Variety has reported Howard Stern Show canceled at SiriusXM, Andy Cohen takes over Stern's channel."
"They're fast," Quivers said.
What Did Stern Say About the Stunt?
After Cohen's segment ended, Stern and Quivers took to the air.
"Lest anyone think that was real, that was all masterminded by me," he said.
Stern went on to thank Cohen for participating in the ruse and called him a "sweetheart."
“I was just sitting here laughing because I just couldn’t imagine what people were thinking when they turned on the radio and heard Andy,” he said.
Stern said all the rumors going around about him and Quivers are “completely false.”
"By the way, I’m absolutely flattered that anybody even cares whether I resign. So I mean, in a way, it was information that I matter," he said.
Stern acknowledged that he has contemplated retirement recently, but said he's now more determined than ever to continue his show.
"Now I can’t because then they’ll say I got pushed out," he said.
The radio personality then said he heard from "a lot of companies who want the show" after all the rumors began.
Still, he wanted to make it clear that he's "very happy at Sirius."
While addressing contract negotiations with SiriusXM, Stern said his team had been in touch with the company before rumors started spreading. He added that SiriusXM has been "nothing but lovely."
SiriusXM declined to comment to NBC News.

title: What Time Are the VMAs? How to Watch
summary: The MTV Video Music Awards are back tonight and expected to bring some of the biggest names in music together once again.
story: The MTV Video Music Awards are back tonight and expected to bring some of the biggest names in music together once again.

The 2025 VMAs, where fans vote for their top artists, songs and performances over the past year, air Sunday, Sept. 7, with LL Cool J set to host. Some famous faces will be presenting awards, including “The Hunting Wives” stars Malin Akerman and Brittany Snow, as well as Jessica Simpson, Drew Barrymore and Ice Spice.
Lady Gaga leads the nominations with 12 nods, with Ariana Grande, Billie Eilish, Bruno Mars, Kendrick Lamar, ROSÉ, Sabrina Carpenter and The Weeknd among the top competitors.
More on the MTV VMAs 2025
MTV VMAs 2025 Live Updates: Follow Along for Red Carpet Looks, Winners, Performers and MoreAll the 2025 MTV VMAs Nominees, Performers and Presenters
MTV VMAs 2025 Live Updates: Follow Along for Red Carpet Looks, Winners, Performers and More
All the 2025 MTV VMAs Nominees, Performers and Presenters
This year brings first-time nominations to 33 artists, including Blake Shelton, Gigi Perez, Lainey Wilson, Mac Miller and Role Model, among others.

In addition to the awards, the VMAs showcase a night full of extravagant performances. The upcoming show has Carpenter, Post Malone, Tate McRae, Jelly Roll, Conan Gray, Sombr and more slated to perform.
The VMAs also celebrate musicians with various honorary awards. This year, Mariah Carey is set to receive the Video Vanguard Award and perform a “career-spanning medley of her biggest hits.”

Meanwhile, Busta Rhymes is expected to be awarded the MTV VMA Rock The Bells Visionary Award. Ricky Martin is set to receive the VMAs first-ever Latin Icon Award. And a tribute to Ozzy Osbourne will be performed by Steven Tyler, Joe Perry, YUNGBLUD and Nuno Bettencourt.
Read on for where to watch the VMAs.
When Are the VMAs?
The 2025 VMAs will take place Sunday, Sept. 7.
What Time Are the VMAs?
The VMAs will begin at 8 p.m. ET/5 p.m. PT.
While the VMAs do not have a set end time, the award show has historically lasted about three hours.
Where Are the VMAs?
The VMAs will be held at UBS Arena on Long Island in New York.
Where to Watch the VMAs
The VMAs will be broadcast live Sunday night on MTV and CBS, as well as on streaming platforms with cable options like Hulu and YouTube TV.
The award show will also be streamed live on Paramount+ for premium plan subscribers.
What to know about the VMAs Pre-Show

Before all the action kicks off at 8 p.m. ET, radio and TV personalities Nessa and Kevan Kenney will host a VMAs pre-show. The pre-show will also include a performance from KATSEYE, a girl group that was formed through the reality competition show "Dream Academy."

The pre-show starts at 7 p.m. ET/4 p.m. PT and will run for one hour. The pre-show is available to watch on MTV, BET, BET Her, Comedy Central, CMT, Logo, MTV2, Nickelodeon, Paramount Network, Pop, TV Land and VH1.
How to Vote for the VMAs
Any person over the age of 12 can vote in the VMAs polls and is allowed up to 10 votes per day.
For most categories, voting ended Friday, Sept. 5. Voting in the category of best new artist ends the same day as the VMAs, Sunday, Sept. 7.

title: Steven Tyler, Joe Perry and More Honor Ozzy Osbourne With VMAs Tribute
summary: The Prince of Darkness received an all-star tribute at the 2025 MTV Video Music Awards from Joe Perry and Steven Tyler; Yungblud; and Extreme's Nuno Bettencourt.
story: The Prince of Darkness received an all-star tribute at the 2025 MTV Video Music Awards.
Before the tribute, Ozzy Osbourne’s son Jack and Jack’s children shared a video message ahead of a montage that aired of some of the late singer’s biggest musical moments.

Ozzy Osbourne, who died at 76 on July 22, was then honored with a musical tribute featuring the legendary Aerosmith duo of Joe Perry and Steven Tyler, British singer Yungblud and Extreme guitarist and singer-songwriter Nuno Bettencourt.

That group combined for a performance Sept. 7 at New York's UBS Arena in tribute to Osbourne, an instrumental figure in the creation of the metal genre and a two-time Rock & Roll Hall of Fame inductee for his time with Black Sabbath and as a solo artist.
The tribute performance consisted of a mix of hits from both Black Sabbath and Osbourne's solo work, including "Crazy Train," "Changes," and "Mama, I'm Coming Home."
Perry, Tyler, and Yungblud closed the performance arm-in-arm at the front of the stage.
Before the show, Yungblud told TODAY.com on the red carpet what Osbourne's last words were to him.
While wearing a necklace the late musician gifted him, Yungblud recalled what Osbourne said to him at Black Sabbath's farewell concert.
“We had a really beautiful moment and I got to thank him for the music. He told me to ‘go and conquer America,’” Yungblud said.
Osbourne also had a long history with MTV, from his early videos to "Headbanger's Ball" and the hit reality series with his family, "The Osbournes."
The rock icon's family said in a statement to NBC News in July that he died "surrounded by love."
Osbourne revealed in 2020 that he had been diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease a year earlier. He died of a heart attack, according to multiple reports.
His last performance came just weeks before his death during Black Sabbath's farewell concert in his hometown of Birmingham, England.
He appeared on a leather throne to sing some of the band's biggest hits as well as his solo classics.

"I don’t know what to say, man, I’ve been laid up for like six years," he told the crowd, according to NBC Chicago. "You have no idea how I feel — thank you from the bottom of my heart. You’re all … special. Let’s go crazy — come on!”

His wife, Sharon Osbourne, and their three children gave him an emotional farewell July 30 during the late rocker's funeral procession in Birmingham. Sharon Osbourne grabbed her kids' hands as she was overcome with emotion for her husband of 43 years.
His Black Sabbath bandmates also honored Osbourne on Instagram and Facebook with a photo of him on the black throne from their final concert.
"Ozzy Forever,” the caption reads.

title: Taylor Swift Does Not Attend 2025 VMAs
summary: Is Taylor Swift attending the VMAs 2025? Here's what to know about her artist of the year nomination and more.
story: Taylor Swift and the MTV VMAs have a long history, one that goes back to 2009 when Swift was a breakthrough country artist. Since then, she has been a VMAs mainstay — and is now the most awarded solo artist in the awards show’s history.

This year, the pop superstar was nominated in one category at the MTV Video Music Awards — artist of the year. Swift also has a lot to celebrate at the moment: She has a new album, “The Life of a Showgirl,” coming in October, and is newly engaged to Travis Kelce.
But it appears Swift had opted out of attending the MTV VMAs time around. Here's what we know.

Swift was nominated this year in one of the VMAs’ top categories: artist of the year. She was in good company with her fellow nominees, including Beyoncé, Lady Gaga, The Weeknd, Bad Bunny, Kendrick Lamar and Morgan Wallen. Lady Gaga ended up nabbing the moon man early on during the VMAs.

In 2024, Swift took home her 30th moon person at the MTV Video Music Awards and solidified her status as the most awarded solo artist in VMAs history. She and Beyoncè are currently tied for most career VMA wins of all time.
While appearing on the Kelce brothers’ “New Heights” podcast in August, Swift announced that she’s releasing her 12th album, “The Life of a Showgirl,” on Oct. 3.
Since Swift and Kelce announced their engagement on Aug. 26, she has been spotted a just a few events.

On Aug. 28, Swift and Kelce made their first appearance together since he popped the question; they attended a football game between the University of Nebraska’s Cornhuskers and the University of Cincinnati’s Bearcats at Arrowhead Stadium.
And on Sept. 2, Brittany Mahomes, wife of Chiefs QB Patrick Mahomes, shared to Instagram photos with Swift from her 30th birthday celebration.
Did Taylor Swift Attend the 2025 MTV VMAs?
Swift did not appear to attend the VMAs this year, despite her nomination for artist of the year.

title: Lady Gaga Accepted Her VMA — And Went to Perform a Full Concert Right After
summary: Lady Gaga Won Artist of The Year at the 2025 MTV VMAs. Then, she performed at Madison Square Garden as part of her "Mayhem Ball" tour.
story: Lady Gaga redefined multitasking on Sunday night.

The pop superstar made a quick, but memorable, appearance at the 2025 MTV VMAs, where she snagged one of the evening’s biggest honors: Artist of the Year. After delivering a heartfelt acceptance speech for the coveted award, Gaga had somewhere else to be.

With 11 additional nominations under her belt for the night, one would think she’d stick around for the rest of the show. Instead, the “Abracadabra” singer had other plans: She was due across town at Madison Square Garden for a concert as part of her popular "Mayhem Ball" tour.
Gaga took to her Instagram story earlier in the evening to alert her fans that tonight's show would be delayed.
"NYC Monsters," she wrote. "I'll be on stage tonight around 9:30 PM🖤 Doors open at 7:00 PM!"
Concertgoers were also notified by Madison Square Garden about the show's delayed start.
Her NYC show marked her final "Mayhem Ball" performance in the city, making it the perfect celebration for her fresh Artist of the Year win.
Gaga marked her big win with an Instagram post after leaving the VMAs for Madison Square Garden.
"MTV VMA ARTIST OF THE YEAR 🌹💀🖤," she captioned a trio of photos.
Though the winner had to leave the ceremony early, it wasn't the last time the musician graced MTV fans' televisions that evening.
She prerecorded an epic performance of her hit single "Abracadabra" and latest release "Dead Dance" at her Madison Square Garden show on Sept. 6.

In a post on X, fans reported from an account called The Mayhem Ball Tour wrote, "Lady Gaga has now finished pre-recording her VMAs performance. She filmed Abracadabra three times and The Dead Dance twice. She wanted to make it extra perfect! Now we’ll have to wait until tomorrow night to see the final version on @MTV."
She recently had to cancel one of her shows in Miami due to “significant risk” of possible long-term damage to her vocal cords.

“Hi everyone I am really so so sorry but I need to postpone tonight’s show in Miami,” she wrote on Instagram right before showtime Sept. 3. "“During rehearsal last night and my vocal warmup tonight my voice was extremely strained and both my dr and vocal coach have advised me not to go on because of the risk it poses."
"I sing live every night — and even though this was a hard and agonizing decision I would be more afraid of the long term implications on my voice," she added.

title: Mariah Carey Receives Video Vanguard Award at MTV’s 2025 VMAs
summary: Mariah Carey performed and received the Video Vanguard Award at the 2025 MTV VMAs.
story: Mariah Carey reflected on the support of her fans and her decades-long career as she was honored with the Video Vanguard Award at the 2025 MTV VMAs.
The icon received the special award from Ariana Grande, who introduced Carey with a sentimental speech, thanking her for creating music that provided the "soundtrack of our lives."
“As a vocalist, there’s only one queen. And that’s Mariah,” Grande said, to applause from the crowd.
Carey took the stage in a satin gold robe that she later took off to reveal a glittering gold bodysuit complete with matching knee-high heels.

The pop star performed a medley of some of her biggest hits, including "Fantasy," "Obsessed," and “We Belong Together,” which is off her 10th studio album, “The Emancipation of Mimi,” which recently celebrated its 20th anniversary.

Carey’s performance marked her return to the VMAs stage for the first time in 20 years. She had also previously presented LL Cool J with the same award in 1997. This time, she was the one being celebrated while the “Around The Way Girl” rapper hosted the Sept. 7 awards show.
While accepting the prestigious honor, Carey poked fun at the fact that this was her first time winning a VMA.
"Thank you so much MTV for giving me the Vanguard Award. I can’t believe I’m getting my first VMA tonight. I just have one question," Carey said, "What in the Sam Hill were you waiting for?"
Jokes aside, Carey shared how creating music videos has been one of her biggest creative outlets throughout her career.
"Music videos are my way of life, of bringing music to my own life," Carey said while accepting the Video Vanguard Award.
"After all this time, I've learned that music evolves, videos evolve, but the fun? That is eternal," she added.

The powerhouse singer first appeared on the VMAs in 1991 when she belted out her song “Emotions” from her second album. She has continued to return to the music awards show over the years, including in 1998 when she opened the show alongside fellow icon Whitney Houston.

With the Video Vanguard Award, Carey, a five-time Grammy winner, adds another impressive accolade to her name. She joins fellow legendary artists, like Beyoncé, Madonna, Janet Jackson, Rihanna and The Beatles, who have also received the video Vanguard Award. Last year, Katy Perry was presented with the award.

In addition to Carey, Busta Rhymes and Ricky Martin had unforgettable nights. Busta Rhymes took the stage before being handed the MTV VMA Rock the Bells Visionary Award, and Martin danced and sang along to some of his most popular songs before winning the Latin Icon Award.

title: 'Hunting Wives' Stars Malin Åkerman, Brittany Snow Are the Cutest Pair on VMAs Red Carpet: See Pics
summary: "The Hunting Wives" co-stars Malin Åkerman and Brittany Snow hit the red carpet at the 2025 MTV Video Music Awards, where they are also presenters.
story: Malin Åkerman and Brittany Snow’s sizzling on-screen chemistry also translates in real life.
The “Hunting Wives” stars swapped their boots for heels during a night out at the 2025 MTV Video Music Awards.
The duo hit the red carpet together Sept. 7, adorably posing for photos. They are also on hand to present during the award show.
Åkerman also shared a photo to her Instagram story of her and Snow from the car on the way to the red carpet.

In the hit series, which is set in east Texas, Åkerman portrays the captivating Margo Banks, who’s in an open marriage of sorts with the town’s aspiring politician. Snow’s Sophie O’Neil moves to town with her husband and becomes fast friends with Margo, and it doesn’t take long for their friendship to turn romantic.

Fans of the show, which was adapted from author May Cobb's book of the same name, quickly began shipping Margo and Sophie. Even the actors themselves seem to love the pairing. Åkerman has reshared fan edits of their characters’ scenes on Instagram, and the two often leave supportive comments on each other’s social media posts.

Last week, Åkerman hung out with two of her other “Hunting Wives” co-stars, Katie Lowes and Jaime Ray Newman, in New York. The trio documented their fun in pics on Instagram, and Snow clearly had FOMO.
“what to do with these jealous feelings!!!” she commented on Lowes’ post, with crying emoji.
She shared a similar sentiment in the comments section of Åkerman’s post.
“*yelling to the sky* whyyyyy am i in LA!!?!” she wrote.
Åkerman replied, promising they would soon have their own fun.
“you were sorely missed 🥰 Soon it’s our turn baby!!! NYC here we come for round 2 😎,” she said.
Their turn first kicked off in Los Angeles on Sept. 6, when Åkerman and Snow presented at the Creative Arts Emmy Awards.

“What a special evening at the @televisionacad with my baby girl @brittanysnow celebrating all the wonderful artistry that TV has to offer 💫 Thanks for having us!” Åkerman captioned a post about the event on Instagram, which featured a carousel of photos of the actor solo and with her co-star.
She also reshared Snow's Instagram story about being each other's “dream date,” adding the smiling face with hearts emoji and the text: “Dream date is right.”

The fun did not stop there, as Snow also shared a video to her Instagram story of them in face masks on a plane to NYC, which Åkerman reposted to her story with the text, “Thx for keeping me hydrated @brittanysnow.”
Åkerman and Snow have previously documented their friendship in fun Instagram posts together.

“Just an appreciation post for this unicorn! Love this girl 💕,” Åkerman captioned an Aug. 4 Instagram post featuring a photo of the two posing in a bar, along with the hashtags #soulsister and #margoandsophie.
“Love you my girl 😭😭😭,” Snow commented on the post.
Snow has shared multiple social media posts with behind-the-scenes snaps from “The Hunting Wives,” including some shots of Åkerman.
The two were also surprised by how many people watched the show.

Åkerman told Jimmy Fallon on “The Tonight Show” she’s been traveling all summer, and she wasn’t aware of the series’ immense popularity. That is, until she noticed her Instagram following increased once “The Hunting Wives” dropped on Netflix in July.
She recalled receiving a text from Snow after a party that said everyone there had seen the show.

“I was like, ‘OK, OK, that’s great,’” Åkerman explained. “She goes, ‘No, no, no. I mean, like, every single person.’ I went, ‘Really? People are actually watching it?’ And she was like, ‘Yeah, they are!’ So it was just like a slow burn because I wasn’t here.”

title: All the 2025 MTV VMAs Nominees, Performers and Presenters
summary: Who is going to the VMAs? See VMA nominations 2025, and a list of performers and presenters.
story: Get ready for MTV’s biggest night because the VMAs are officially back.
The 2025 MTV Video Music Awards nominees, performers and presenters have been revealed in the walk-up to the show, airing live Sept. 7, and can give viewers a hint at who might be attending.

Lady Gaga leads in nominations this year with 12, including nods for video of the year, artist of the year and best album.  It’s Gaga’s third time as the top contender at the VMAs, a feat she also pulled off in 2010 and 2020. Other top nominees this year include Bruno Mars (11), Kendrick Lamar (10), and ROSÉ and Sabrina Carpenter (eight each).
Two new categories have been added this year: best country and best pop artist.

Top and emerging artists will hit the stage to this year, too; Mariah Carey will perform as the 2025 Video Vanguard Award honoree. Plus, Busta Rhymes and Ricky Martin will take the mic in separate performances, as they receive the Rock the Bells Visionary Award and the Latin Icon Award, respectively.
Aerosmith’s Steven Tyler and Joe Perry, as well as YUNGBLUD and Nuno Bettencourt, will also perform a tribute to heavy metal legend Ozzy Osbourne, who died in July.
Sabrina Carpenter, Lady Gaga, Post Malone, Jelly Roll and KATSEYE are among other performers.
As for presenters, expect to see “The Hunting Wives” stars Malin Akerman and Brittany Snow, as well as Jessica Simpson, Drew Barrymore, Ice Spice and more.
The 2025 MTV VMAs air live from the UBS Arena in Elmont, New York, on Sunday, Sept. 7, at 8 p.m. ET/5 p.m. PT on CBS. The show will be simulcast on MTV and stream on Paramount+.

title: Billy Porter Recovering From ‘Serious Case’ of Sepsis as Broadway’s ‘Cabaret’ Sets Early Closing Date
summary: Broadway's revival of "Cabaret" is closing early as star Billy Porter withdraws from the show while recovering from sepsis
story: Broadway's revival of "Cabaret" is closing early as star Billy Porter withdraws from the show while recovering from sepsis.
Porter was slated to perform as the Emcee for 13 weeks until Oct. 19, opposite Marisha Wallace as Sally Bowles. The production has now set its final performance date for Sept. 21.
Porter had to withdraw from the show "due to a serious case of sepsis," the production said in a statement on Instagram Sept. 7.
"His doctors are confident that he will make a full recovery but have advised him to maintain a restful schedule," the statement read.
TODAY.com has reached out to representatives for Porter for further comment on his health.
Producer Adam Speers called Porter "an extraordinary 'Emcee'" in a statement.
"We wish Billy a speedy recovery and I look forward to working with him again in the very near future," Speers said.
Regarding the decision to close the production early, Speers said the "painful" decision was made "with a heavy heart."

"On behalf of all the producers, we’re so honored to have been able to bring this version of John Kander, Fred Ebb, and Joe Masteroff’s important masterpiece, Cabaret, to New York and to have opened the doors to our own Kit Kat Club for the year and a half we have been here," Speers said.

"Cabaret" began previews at the August Wilson Theatre in April 2024 and originally starred Eddie Redmayne as the Emcee and Gayle Rankin as Sally Bowles. Since then, a slew of celebrities have taken the stage at the Kit Kat Club, including Adam Lambert, Orville Peck, Auliʻi Cravalho and Eva Noblezada.
Marty Lauter and David Merino will perform as the Emcee during the show’s final two weeks, with a schedule to be announced at a later date.
Porter wasn’t new to the role of Emcee, having previously portrayed the character in the show's West End production from Jan. 28, 2025, through May 24, 2025, per Playbill.
The actor reflected on his Broadway homecoming during a July appearance on TODAY.

“The last time I was on Broadway was about nine years ago, and I feel comfort. I feel like I’m home,” Porter said. “This was the original dream and to be back, I will always come back to the theater.”
He compared returning to the role of the Emcee to "getting on a bike."
“My mind kind of came back,” Porter said. “It’s still there. It was not deleted from the files, yet.”
The actor also reflected on the progress made on Broadway over his decades-long career, telling Al Roker it was “different” and “better,” but there was still “a long way to go still.”

“Me playing the Emcee was not possible 30 years ago when I got here,” he explained. “I tried to audition. I couldn’t even get an audition. They said, ‘That’s not the story we’re telling.’ So, things have changed, and I want to make sure that I say that. It’s so easy to lean into the negative of things, and I want to make sure that there are lots of positive things happening.”

title: Sylvester Stallone Shares How Facing Abuse as a Child Led to his Love of Acting
summary: On "Sunday Sitdown with Willie Geist," Sylvester Stallone opened up about his rough childhood and revealed how that got him into acting.
story: Sylvester Stallone is getting candid about his upbringing.
During a Sept. 7 appearance on Sunday Sitdown with Willie Geist, Stallone recalled the abuse he faced by his father as a kid and how it ultimately made him want to be an actor.

"There’s this incredible sense of emptiness because why couldn’t it have been like, a pleasant upbringing? Why did it have to be so dark?" he said. "But would I have been here if it was a pleasant — hell, like, 'The Waltons'? It wasn’t."
Having a tumultuous relationship with his father, he started to look for "a real male role model" elsewhere, he said. That's when his love for acting and performance began.
"And I couldn’t find it. It certainly wasn’t around the house," he said. "And it wasn’t until I went to the movie theater, but I was never into, like, real serious actors. I was into escapism."

The "Tulsa King" star ended up dropping out of the University of Miami to pursue acting in New York City. At 23, he moved to the Big Apple to hopefully get some roles, but he was typecast in smaller parts.

That was when Stallone decided to take his career into his own hands. The "Creed" star sat down and wrote the highly acclaimed movie "Rocky." The film starred Stallone as a small-time Philadelphia boxer who gets the chance to take on the world heavyweight champion.

Though the film saw much success, Stallone says that studios didn't want him to star in it because they wanted an established actor to take the lead role. Stallone famously insisted he could do the job and turned down an offer of $360,000 to not be in the movie.
While speaking with Willie, he remembered what he told himself years ago when he was first presented with the offer.

“'This is basically you, Sly. If you get rid of this, yes, you’ll have $360 grand,' which was worth a lot more back then, 'but that will go. Eventually, that will be gone, and you’ll be the most bitter human being, because the entire thing was not about selling out,'" he said.
"It was about integrity. And I said, if I let this go, I’m letting my life go ‘cause I’m never going to find this again, never," he added.

Stallone's decision to not give up the role proved inspirational for other actors. Willie said Matt Damon once told him that he and Ben Affleck insisted on playing the lead roles in "Good Will Hunting," a movie they wrote together, because of Stallone.
"Thank you. Thank you, guys," Stallone said after hearing that.
Since "Rocky," Stallone has gone on to appear in films like "Rambo" and "The Expendables."
Now, the three-time Academy Award nominee will be honored in December at the 2025 Kennedy Center Honors.
